Award.AwardTitle: Probing Carrier Dynamics in Novel Metal/Semiconductor Nanocomposites
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Abstract
Nanocomposites in which semimetallic rare-earth-monopnictide (RE-V) nanoparticles are epitaxially embedded within III-V semiconductors are an exciting new class of electronic materials. The unique properties of these nanocomposites have already led to improved performance in prototype devices ranging from thermoelectrics to tunnel junctions. Despite this progress, the fundamental nanoscale physical properties of these nanocomposites remain poorly understood. For example, both the source of carriers and the interfacial contributions to charge transport and energy relaxation remain unknown. In this grant, well-characterized InAs quantum dots will be used as a local probe of the properties of single RE-V nanoparticles. The single nanoparticle spectroscopy will be complemented by ensemble ultrafast optical and terahertz spectroscopy. The ultrafast measurements will quantify the dynamic properties of the nanocomposites while the single nanoparticle spectroscopy will enable development of a microscopic theory of material properties. In addition to allowing measurements of single nanoparticles, the incorporation of quantum dots will provide a new tool for unprecedented control over growth morphology and the production of radically new nanocomposite structures.
Non-Technical Abstract
This grant supports efforts to fundamentally understand a technologically-relevant nanocomposites system. The comprehensive understanding of nanoscale physical properties developed through this grant will lead directly to practical applications with far-reaching impacts, including improved energy harvesting devices and significant advances in terahertz science and technology. Two graduate students will be exposed to a highly interdisciplinary environment, and K-12 students in local schools will benefit from teacher training activities and also the creation of educational equipment that will be loaned to local schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Semiconductor materials are at the heart of many technologies that have become essential to modern life. These technologies include the electronic circuits that enable computers, cell phones and other information processing devices, the light sources and detectors that enable rapid information transmission over the internet and the sensors that keep us safe by monitoring for environmental or security hazards. Future advances in these technologies require development of new materials with specific properties tailored for device applications.

The purpose of this research was to explore a new class of semiconductor materials with properties that we anticipated would be of use for certain types of devices. A fundamental property of semiconductors is that they do not conduct electricity unless some external stimulus, for example light, gives an electron enough extra energy to become free and start to move. The two most important properties that we investigated were bandgap and carrier lifetime. The bandgap is the amount of energy that has to be absorbed to dislodge an electron and allow current to flow. The carrier lifetime is how long that electron will continue to move before becoming trapped again.

The new materials we created included nanoparticles containing rare-earth atoms embedded within conventional semiconductors. We found that the inclusion of these rare-earth components led to the creation of very small traps with a small bandgap. The traps provided a path for electron relaxation and thus led to very short carrier lifetimes. We measured the bandgaps and the lifetimes using a variety of techniques that measured the absorption and emission of light on very short time scales. We used many iterations of material synthesis and measurement to systematically explore the relationship between the material composition, the synthesis conditions and the measured properties. Using the results of these experiments, we created a framework that will enable the design of materials with specific properties tailored for device applications. The materials are likely to be particularly useful for devices in which the emission of light needs to be modulated very quickly and in materials for environmentally-friendly thermoelectric (thermal to electrical) generation of electricity.

In parallel with our scientific research, we used support from this award to improve the dissemination of hands-on modules for K-12 education and outreach. The educational modules we have developed include the physical apparatus required to conduct hands-on experiments and supporting documentation about the underlying scientific ideas. These modules are available for free loan to any local K-12 teacher, librarian or informal science education organization. UD students and staff routinely take these modules to informal science education events. Over the past year, 7461 students were exposed to Lending Library module content at formal and informal science education venues including classrooms, 4-Youth programs, public libraries, UD summer camps, Family Engineering Day on the National Mall and a local minor-league basketball game.
